instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3332: What is 820-3332? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PP5V_S0: What is PP5V_S0? PP5V_S0 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S0 working state..
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PM_SLP_S3_L: What is PM_SLP_S3_L? PM_SLP_S3_L puts the machine to sleep in an S3 state when it is asserted, the _L means it is asserted when it is low voltage. When this signal is 3.3v the machine will be asked to turn on S0 power rails and begin the bootup process.
definitions.PPVCORE_S0_CPU: What is PPVCORE_S0_CPU? This is the primary power rail for the CPU that powers the CPU, known as CPU vcore. Without this, the machine will be braindead. .
definitions.PP1V05_S0:
What is PP1V05_S0? The PP1V05_S0 power rail is for various components on the logic board that require a 1.05V supply voltage in the S0 (on) state. This voltage rail is likely to be used by the CPU (for VCCIO), PCH (Platform Controller Hub).

.
definitions.PPVCORE_GPU: What is PPVCORE_GPU? This is the main power rail for the GPU. This is required for the GPU to turn on so you can get image on the display. .
definitions.PP1V8_S0: What is PP1V8_S0? PP1V8_S0 is a power rail that is present when the machine is in an S0 state, meaning it is fully turned on, not sleeping or hiberating .
definitions.PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC: What is PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC? PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC Is a reference voltage for the SMC’s voltage sensors & other sensors..
definitions.PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT: What is PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT? PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT is a 0.75v power rail present when the machine is in an S0 working state .
definitions.PPVTTDDR_S3: What is PPVTTDDR_S3? PPVTTDDR_S3 is a 3.3v power rail that powers the DDR RAM when the machine is in an S3 suspend to RAM state. .
definitions.U8900: What is U8900? This chip creates the GPU power rails on the 820-3332 board to the 2012 and early 2013 15” Retina Macbook Pros. It becomes desoldered and is the cause of no video and kernel panics/crashes in that model most of the time..
definitions.ALL_SYS: What is ALL_SYS? This is a typo of ALL_SYS_PWRGD When you see ALL_SYS, assume they meant to type ALL_SYS_PWRGD.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power rails fluctuating
threads.message:
I'm working on this <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> thats got me pretty confused. when the machine came in it powered on then the screen would go black at the apple screen and keep running, The tech working on it powered it up on smc bypass and now the board doesn't power on fully. i get the left fan to spin for about 1 second then turn off then back on continuously. 

i tested the power rails and this is what i get.

<SIGNAL>PPUBS_G3H</SIGNAL>- 12.6v
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL>- 3.42v
<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>- 16.1v pulses to 20.02v
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S3_L</SIGNAL>- 0.0v pulses to 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP0V75_S0_DDRVTT</SIGNAL>- 0.0v- pulses to .023v
<SIGNAL>PP1V05_S0</SIGNAL>- 0.0v pulses to 1.05v
<SIGNAL>PP1V8_S0</SIGNAL>- 0.0v pulses to 1.7v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL>- 0.103v pulses to 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0GPU</SIGNAL>- 0v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL>- 0.25v pulses to 3.3
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL>- 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5_AVREF_SMC</SIGNAL>- 3.3v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S0</SIGNAL>- 0.26v pulses to 2.6v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL> 0.16v drops to 0.098v pulses to 00.8v
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL>- 5.02v
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_GPU</SIGNAL>- 0.0v
<SIGNAL>PPVCORE_S0_CPU</SIGNAL>- 0.0v
<SIGNAL>PPVTTDDR_S3</SIGNAL>- 0.012v pulses to 0.5v 
<SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL>- 0.0v pulses to 3.3v

im so confused on this one. anyone got some ideas as where to start on this one?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power rails fluctuating
threads.message: So it is power cycling, could be anything. Did someone stab it with screwdriver or multimeter? Corrosion? <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> desoldered and checked it's outputs for shorts?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power rails fluctuating
threads.message:
the power cycling issues happened prior to even being opened up, so i dont think it got stabbed with anything. there is literally no corrosion or signs of being dropped.

diod mode on these pins indicate shorts to ground with <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> removed.

pin12 0.015v
pin13 0.0v
pin21 0.015v
pin22 0.0v
pin27 0.0v
pin28 0.015v
pin40 0.0v

based on pins 12 & 13 readings im guessing this is not a good sign for the <CHIP>U8000</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power rails fluctuating
threads.message: Resistance to GND on the same pins?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power rails fluctuating
threads.message:
pin12 30.1ohms
pin13 0.5 ohms

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power rails fluctuating
threads.message: That's fine, put the chip back.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power rails fluctuating
threads.message: sure thing. not sure whats going on with this board. i want to start looking at cpu vcore, but get to bios and its not getting what it needs just power cycles. kinda a rabbit hole for me.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power rails fluctuating
threads.message: do you think this could be a possible smc issue?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power rails fluctuating
threads.message: Wait, you powered the board without <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> installed?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power rails fluctuating
threads.message: no ive already put the <CHIP>U8900</CHIP> back on.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power rails fluctuating
threads.message: CPU Vcore pulsing? <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL> pulsing?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power rails fluctuating
threads.message: CPU Vcore stays at 0.0v <SIGNAL>ALL_SYS</SIGNAL> pulsing for 0.03v to 2.9v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power rails fluctuating
threads.message: So no Vcore, this could be absolutely anything. If this machine came in working then someone fucked something up and it could be any knocked off component or something.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power rails fluctuating
threads.message: i would normally agree with you on that, had it been opened up before screwing up but thats not the case. machine came in we always power on to verify the customer issue if possible. Thats where it started going sideways. way before it even got close to a screw driver.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power rails fluctuating
threads.message: Doesn't change the fact that it could be anything. Without any history this one will be a rabbit hole.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power rails fluctuating
threads.message: agreed. i did some checking around on the board and found that pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R9840</RESISTOR> is shorted to ground. im thinking there is an issue with <CHIP>U1800</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power rails fluctuating
threads.message: Resistance to GND there?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power rails fluctuating
threads.message: 46ohms. so not short to ground. not understanding why diode mode shows 0.004ohms?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power rails fluctuating
threads.message: Because diode mode is not resistance and every multimeter is different with diode mode.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3332</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> power rails fluctuating
threads.message: ahhh i see. yea this one is just screwed im thinking. i never had one go all to shit while here and not messing with it. i think this rabbit hole is gonna just be a board replacement.
